snippet: Investigators are searching for as many as 21 women who are believed to include prostitutes and to have spent the night with a group of security officers.
abstract: American investigators seeking to get to the bottom of reported misconduct of a group of Secret Service agents and military personnel assigned to Pres Obama's visit to Colombia are looking to interview as many as 21 women who are believed to include prostitutes and to have spent the night with security officers in Cartagena; the women are said to have accompanied 11 agents to their hotel rooms after a night of heavy drinking; incident casts a spotlight on Colombian city where prostitution is legal in 'tolerance zones.'

byline.original: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
byline.contributor: William Neuman reported from Cartagena, and Michael S. Schmidt from Washington. Thom Shanker and Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington, and Jenny Carolina González from Bogotá, Colombia.

lead_paragraph: Investigators are searching for as many as 21 women who are believed to include prostitutes and to have spent the night with a group of security officers.

headline.seo: Secret Service Inquiries Trace Women in Colombia
headline.main: In Agent Scandal, Inquiry Leads to Colombian Bordellos
headline.print_headline: Agent Scandal: Inquiry Leads To the Bordello

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
